comment_body.0:
Location: NH, USA

Price range: Ideally under 40K, could stretch to about 55k for the right car

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: most likely new, but willing to consider 3 year lease returns and the like

Type of vehicle: Hatch or crossover

Must haves: AWD, space for family of 3 including car seat, luxury or near luxury interior, modern features (heated/cooled seats, android auto, adaptive cruise), decent driving dynamics (I realize it's not going to be a sports car, but I don't want something as transport appliance as the CR-V I drove and hated.)

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): auto or DCT

Intended use: Daily Driver/Family Car,

Vehicles you've already considered: CX-5 (top contender), mach E (interior too crappy for the money, dislike giant touchscreen), ID4 (really bad acceleration for an EV), Crosstrek (practical, but not that fun), used Golf R (loved driving it, but I think it's just over the line for a daily in terms of ride / comfort), Macan (brilliant, but everything is optional, so it's way too expensive), X1 (bumpy ride without the handling improvement to show for it, more road noise), CRV (super practical, but terrible to drive), XC40 (liked but didn't love)

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: Yes

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: (fluids, alternator, battery, brake pads etc): yes, but I don't really want to

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: I'm coming from a 2009 Honda Fit, which I've loved, but I want more room and a lot more refinement. Cars listed above are ones I've driven. I also am thinking about the A5 Sportback, but it's pushing it on length for my short garage.

So far the CX-5 is the leading contender. Basically everything I drove higher in price short of the Macan wasn't better enough to feel worth it. I adored the Macan, but I just can't justify spending the money to myself, and the fact that it has carplay but not android auto just pisses me off. Also, the cargo space is a bit small.

Anything else I should try?

Recently a stunning, manual Arctic Silver 2.5 Porsche Boxster with a Terracotta softtop and interior popped up on my local classifieds. It has a little under 100k miles (150k km, I'm in Europe).

My girlfriend (30F) and I (29M) have been contemplating buying an 'affordable' convertible for some spirited weekend driving since we drive boring company cars during the week. The thing is I have little to none experience maintaining and wrenching on cars myself other than doing preventive maintenance and the odd oil change. We can definitely easily afford its asking price, but I don't have a clue how the costly Porsche repairs can add up down the line.

Any advice is appreciated.

Back

Interior

Location: Ontario, Canada

Intended use: Daily Driver, Weekend Car, maybe AutoX

Vehicles you've already considered: STI, 981/987.2, Focus RS, ND2, GR86, Mustang GT

Is this your 1st vehicle: Yes (Been driving my parents' car daily for 2.5 years though, would be MY first car)

Do you need a Warranty: Preferably

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: No, but I want to learn

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes:

My goal is to get a 718 cayman gts 4.0 at some point in the future (5 years +), which will be my one gas car to keep forever. So for now I'd like to get a fun car to drive, whether it be rwd/manual or the unlimited grip feeling of an awd. Either something that doesn't depreciate too much so I can sell it in the future to help me get a big chunk of down payment for the gts or a cheap enough car to last me 5 years or so.

At this point I've done so much research that I have analysis paralysis? Decision paralysis? Here's a quick summary of my thinking:

Miata/86: manual/rwd cornering cars, these would teach me how to drive. Probably the most sensible one. But I don't really feel super excited about the thought of owning one for some reason.

981/987.2: These will keep their value the most I think? Great sound, fast enough for me, handles great too. Great middle ground between miata/86 and mustang. Long gears.

Mustang GT: Sounds amazing, handles well, not as good compared to the above 2. Probably too much power for me. MT82 has some issues, long gears. Also concerned about the drivability of this v8 beast in Ontario winters.

STI: The idea of having the confidence to drive at any weather is amazing, and the car sounds pretty good too. Holds value really well. Reliability concerns, but if I buy it new/lease and keep it stock, shouldn't be a problem. Won't really teach me how to drive though. The most mechanical car out of the bunch here I think?

Focus RS: Same as STI really, but no warranty. I like the way it looks too.

Additional Notes:

Accord Hybrid

+++Great price. Very good fuel economy.

+Heard the adaptive cruise control (ACC) is pretty good. (honestly don't see the benfit of Tesla autopilot (aka Tesla ACC) over Honda ACC; hoping for insight here). I am not comparing Honda ACC to Tesla "full-self-driving."

---Commonly hear complaints of the road noise, and the stock speakers (and premium stock speakers) are considered bad. My personal experience with older models aligns with this sentiment. I am unclear how I would go about upgrading the audio. I think Honda uses noise canceling mics to help with it's already terrible road noise. They might need to be disable for an aftermarket install? I am not sure if I would feel comfortable doing the install myself. (could be up to 2-5k extra for parts +installation)

Tesla Model 3 LR

+++phenomenal speakers (heard them personally and love them.)

+Phone as a key seems super cool. Even though the honda will have keyless entry, the fact that I don't have to carry a fob for the Tesla is a tangible benefit in my eyes.

+okay road noise (mixed reviews).

+Fuel economy is obviously great, but not much savings when compared to the accord hybrid (maybe $500/year savings in fuel costs by my estimate for my situation).

+Will most definitely be a fun driving experience, however I am not sure if it is worth the cost me for me personally.

+Will have access to home charging

+placed a reservation for the car, so won't have to wait too long if I decide to buy it.

-50%-70% highway driving; worse efficiency for battery cars in the highway, especially above 65mph. (i am used to cruising around 70+mph, though I can adapt)

---Very expensive (+20k). I can afford it, but I constantly think about the opportunity cost of not saving the money. I am holding out for updates on any tax credits. There might be an update this month on the status.

Tesla Model 3 SR+

++ Better cost (~45k OTD)

+Similar benefits to the LR

--Speakers are not as good as the LR. I am not clear if an audio upgrade is possible. or feasible (lack of wiring from Tesla to add additional speakers+sub, like in the LR).

--Wait time is long. New orders are being fulfilled next year.

--Worry about regrets of not getting LR.

Also Considering: Lexus ES 300h (~48k OTD)

+++Great speakers, Low road noise

+++Decent MPGs (~44)

-Probably the least "exciting" car.

--pricey

---not a fan of the looks.
